title: Jabberwock

A **jabberwock**, J, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is the only utilized monster in the [jabberwock](/wiki/Jabberwock_\(monster_class\) "Jabberwock (monster class)") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") - the [vorpal jabberwock](/wiki/Vorpal_jabberwock "Vorpal jabberwock") is also a part of the monster class, but is [deferred](/wiki/Deferred "Deferred").

Jabberwocks are [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal") that are capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight"), can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), and will pick up and collect items. A jabberwock will be instantly [beheaded](/wiki/Behead "Behead") if hit by [Vorpal Blade](/wiki/Vorpal_Blade "Vorpal Blade").

A jabberwock has two bite attacks and two claw attacks.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

  - [2.1 As a polyform](#As_a_polyform)
  - [2.2 As a pet](#As_a_pet)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [6.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated jabberwocks are always created hostile, and are generated asleep 4⁄5 of the time unless you have the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Jabberwocks can be generated by the [summon nasties](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").

Two jabberwocks are generated on the [Plane of Air](/wiki/Plane_of_Air "Plane of Air") at level creation.

## Strategy

Jabberwocks hit hard and often enough to offset their -2 [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and 12 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), which are decent but not remotely insurmountable, and it may occasionally be wiser to leave sleeping jabberwocks undisturbed. Unfortunately, by the time that a jabberwock can be encountered normally, most characters will already be encountering hostile spellcasters: they can either use the [aggravate](/wiki/Aggravate "Aggravate") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") to wake sleeping monsters, or summon nasties and generate one directly adjacent to you. The jabberwock's [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 50 makes many [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell") and [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") unreliable against it, though it thankfully has no elemental resistances.

In any event, even a [stealthy](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth") character should be prepared to fight a jabberwock directly at some point, and should not count on jabberwocks that generate asleep to remain so for long. [Polymorph traps](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap") and [shapeshifters](/wiki/Shapeshifter "Shapeshifter") such as [chameleons](/wiki/Chameleon "Chameleon") can present an unwelcome and [possibly game-ending](/wiki/YAAD "YAAD") obstacle if a monster takes the form of a jabberwock while closing in on you, and both can occur well before they would generate normally. A character that has access to Vorpal Blade can easily dispatch any jabberwock they come across - other characters that are prepared for the lower dungeons can usually fight one off with some difficulty, and should take as much care as possible not to let it breach melee range.

### As a polyform

The jabberwock is a very strong polyform due to its flight, strength, four attacks with high damage output, and the ability to wear all non-body armor.

### As a pet

Jabberwocks are very strong pets, and are among the most powerful flying monsters that can serve as [steeds](/wiki/Steed "Steed"). Relative to [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon"), they are significantly faster and deal much more melee damage, but their lack of resistances and reflection leaves them vulnerable to a variety of [instadeaths](/wiki/Instadeath "Instadeath").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Pets can gain resistances by eating corpses. A properly-fed and hasted jabberwock may have survivability comparable to the [inediate](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate") [ki-rin](/wiki/Ki-rin "Ki-rin").

## History

The jabberwock first appears in [NetHack 3.0.5](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.5 "NetHack 3.0.5").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Jabberwocky](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jabberwocky "wikipedia:Jabberwocky")***

The jabberwock is a creature featured in *Jabberwocky*, a famous nonsense poem by [Lewis Carroll](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Carroll "wikipedia:Lewis Carroll"), and its [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") entry is an excerpt from the poem. *Jabberwocky* is first printed in Carroll's 1871 novel *[Through the Looking-Glass](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Through_the_Looking-Glass "wikipedia:Through the Looking-Glass")*, the sequel to the 1865 *[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland "wikipedia:Alice's Adventures in Wonderland")*.

Alice finds herself in a looking-glass world and encounters the poem as part of a book written in a seemingly unintelligible language; she shortly discovers the text and the world at large is in fact inverted (or mirrored), and holds a mirror to the poem to read it, finding it as puzzling as the odd land she is now in. The poem is also the inspiration for the [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") Vorpal Blade, based on the unnamed adventurer's weapon that is used to behead the jabberwock - this is also the basis for the jabberwock's weakness to Vorpal Blade.

The original illustrations by [John Tenniel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Tenniel "wikipedia:John Tenniel") accompanying the poem (and the rest of the two novels) depict the titular jabberwock as a bipedal creature that vaguely resembles a dragon: It has bat-like wings, a long serpentine neck, a long tail, a weird head with rabbit-like teeth, hands with three long spidery talons, and a waistcoat. Some of the jabberwock's more particular traits may reflect the contemporary Victorian obsession with natural history and the then-fast-evolving sciences of paleontology and geology.

## Messages

- The jabberwock burbles.

  You [chatted](/wiki/Chat "Chat") to a jabberwock.

## Variants

Many variants implement the vorpal jabberwock in some manner, while comparatively few make significant changes to the jabberwock itself.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), jabberwocks [hit as +1 weapons](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon").

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), weapons with the [vorpal](/wiki/Vorpal "Vorpal") [object property](/wiki/Object_property "Object property") can also instantly behead jabberwocks.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), jabberwocks have an increased base level and damage dice that matches those of the vorpal jabberwock in vanilla *NetHack*. A jabberwock can also follow you to other levels if it is adjacent, and will not generate in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom").

A jabberwock may be one of the monsters generated within a [magic item vault](/wiki/Special_room_\(dNetHack\)#Magic_item_vault "Special room (dNetHack)").

## Encyclopedia entry

"Beware the Jabberwock, my son!  
  The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!  
Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun  
  The frumious Bandersnatch!"  
  
He took his vorpal sword in hand;  
  Long time the manxome foe he sought --  
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,  
  And stood awhile in thought.  
  
And, as in uffish thought he stood,  
  The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame,  
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,  
  And burbled as it came!  
  
One, two! One, two! And through and through  
  The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
  He went galumphing back.

\[ Jabberwocky, by Lewis Carroll ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1262](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1262): *chance of jabberwocks being generated asleep*

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Jabberwock

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
For the monster class, see jabberwock (monster class).
J jabberwock
Difficulty 18
Attacks Bite 2d10, bite 2d10, claw 2d10, claw 2d10
J jabberwock
Difficulty 18
Attacks

Bite 2d10, bite 2d10, claw 2d10, claw 2d10

Base level 15
Base experience 489
Speed 12
Base AC -2
Base MR 50
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1300
Nutritional value 600
Size Large
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A jabberwock:

  • can fly.
  • is an animal.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line1576

A jabberwock, J, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is the only utilized monster in the jabberwock monster class - the vorpal jabberwock is also a part of the monster class, but is deferred.

Jabberwocks are strong carnivorous animals that are capable of flight, can be seen via infravision, and will pick up and collect items. A jabberwock will be instantly beheaded if hit by Vorpal Blade.

A jabberwock has two bite attacks and two claw attacks.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
    • 2.1 As a polyform
    • 2.2 As a pet
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 GruntHack
    • 6.3 dNetHack
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

Randomly generated jabberwocks are always created hostile, and are generated asleep 4⁄5 of the time unless you have the Amulet of Yendor.[1]

Jabberwocks can be generated by the summon nasties monster spell.

Two jabberwocks are generated on the Plane of Air at level creation.

Strategy

Jabberwocks hit hard and often enough to offset their -2 AC and 12 speed, which are decent but not remotely insurmountable, and it may occasionally be wiser to leave sleeping jabberwocks undisturbed. Unfortunately, by the time that a jabberwock can be encountered normally, most characters will already be encountering hostile spellcasters: they can either use the aggravate monster spell to wake sleeping monsters, or summon nasties and generate one directly adjacent to you. The jabberwock's MR score of 50 makes many spells and wands unreliable against it, though it thankfully has no elemental resistances.

In any event, even a stealthy character should be prepared to fight a jabberwock directly at some point, and should not count on jabberwocks that generate asleep to remain so for long. Polymorph traps and shapeshifters such as chameleons can present an unwelcome and possibly game-ending obstacle if a monster takes the form of a jabberwock while closing in on you, and both can occur well before they would generate normally. A character that has access to Vorpal Blade can easily dispatch any jabberwock they come across - other characters that are prepared for the lower dungeons can usually fight one off with some difficulty, and should take as much care as possible not to let it breach melee range.

As a polyform

The jabberwock is a very strong polyform due to its flight, strength, four attacks with high damage output, and the ability to wear all non-body armor.

As a pet

Jabberwocks are very strong pets, and are among the most powerful flying monsters that can serve as steeds. Relative to dragons, they are significantly faster and deal much more melee damage, but their lack of resistances and reflection leaves them vulnerable to a variety of instadeaths.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Pets can gain resistances by eating corpses. A properly-fed and hasted jabberwock may have survivability comparable to the inediate ki-rin.

History

The jabberwock first appears in NetHack 3.0.5.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Jabberwocky

The jabberwock is a creature featured in Jabberwocky, a famous nonsense poem by Lewis Carroll, and its encyclopedia entry is an excerpt from the poem. Jabberwocky is first printed in Carroll's 1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass, the sequel to the 1865 Alice's Adventures in Wonderland.

Alice finds herself in a looking-glass world and encounters the poem as part of a book written in a seemingly unintelligible language; she shortly discovers the text and the world at large is in fact inverted (or mirrored), and holds a mirror to the poem to read it, finding it as puzzling as the odd land she is now in. The poem is also the inspiration for the artifact weapon Vorpal Blade, based on the unnamed adventurer's weapon that is used to behead the jabberwock - this is also the basis for the jabberwock's weakness to Vorpal Blade.

The original illustrations by John Tenniel accompanying the poem (and the rest of the two novels) depict the titular jabberwock as a bipedal creature that vaguely resembles a dragon: It has bat-like wings, a long serpentine neck, a long tail, a weird head with rabbit-like teeth, hands with three long spidery talons, and a waistcoat. Some of the jabberwock's more particular traits may reflect the contemporary Victorian obsession with natural history and the then-fast-evolving sciences of paleontology and geology.

Messages

The jabberwock burbles.
You chatted to a jabberwock.

Variants

Many variants implement the vorpal jabberwock in some manner, while comparatively few make significant changes to the jabberwock itself.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, jabberwocks hit as +1 weapons.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, weapons with the vorpal object property can also instantly behead jabberwocks.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, jabberwocks have an increased base level and damage dice that matches those of the vorpal jabberwock in vanilla NetHack. A jabberwock can also follow you to other levels if it is adjacent, and will not generate in Gehennom.

A jabberwock may be one of the monsters generated within a magic item vault.

Encyclopedia entry

"Beware the Jabberwock, my son!
  The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun
  The frumious Bandersnatch!"

He took his vorpal sword in hand;
  Long time the manxome foe he sought --
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
  And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
  The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
  And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
  The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
  He went galumphing back.

[ Jabberwocky, by Lewis Carroll ]

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1262: chance of jabberwocks being generated asleep

A '''jabberwock''', {{monsym|jabberwock}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is the only utilized monster in the [[Jabberwock (monster class)|jabberwock]] [[monster class]] - the [[vorpal jabberwock]] is also a part of the monster class, but is [[deferred]].

Jabberwocks are [[strong]] [[carnivorous]] [[animal]]s that are capable of [[flight]], can be seen via [[infravision]], and will pick up and collect items. A jabberwock will be instantly [[behead]]ed if hit by [[Vorpal Blade]].

A jabberwock has two bite attacks and two claw attacks.

==Generation==
Randomly generated jabberwocks are always created hostile, and are generated asleep {{frac|4|5}} of the time unless you have the [[Amulet of Yendor]].{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1262|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=chance of jabberwocks being generated asleep}}

Jabberwocks can be generated by the [[summon nasties]] [[monster spell]].

Two jabberwocks are generated on the [[Plane of Air]] at level creation.

==Strategy==
Jabberwocks hit hard and often enough to offset their -2 [[AC]] and 12 [[speed]], which are decent but not remotely insurmountable, and it may occasionally be wiser to leave sleeping jabberwocks undisturbed. Unfortunately, by the time that a jabberwock can be encountered normally, most characters will already be encountering hostile spellcasters: they can either use the [[aggravate]] [[monster spell]] to wake sleeping monsters, or summon nasties and generate one directly adjacent to you.  The jabberwock's [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] of 50 makes many [[spell]]s and [[wand]]s unreliable against it, though it thankfully has no elemental resistances.

In any event, even a [[stealth]]y character should be prepared to fight a jabberwock directly at some point, and should not count on jabberwocks that generate asleep to remain so for long. [[Polymorph trap]]s and [[shapeshifter]]s such as [[chameleon]]s can present an unwelcome and [[YAAD|possibly game-ending]] obstacle if a monster takes the form of a jabberwock while closing in on you, and both can occur well before they would generate normally. A character that has access to Vorpal Blade can easily dispatch any jabberwock they come across - other characters that are prepared for the lower dungeons can usually fight one off with some difficulty, and should take as much care as possible not to let it breach melee range.

===As a polyform===
The jabberwock is a very strong polyform due to its flight, strength, four attacks with high damage output, and the ability to wear all non-body armor.

===As a pet===
Jabberwocks are very strong pets, and are among the most powerful flying monsters that can serve as [[steed]]s. Relative to [[dragon]]s, they are significantly faster and deal much more melee damage, but their lack of resistances and reflection leaves them vulnerable to a variety of [[instadeath]]s.

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Pets can gain resistances by eating corpses. A properly-fed and hasted jabberwock may have survivability comparable to the [[inediate]] [[ki-rin]].}}

==History==
The jabberwock first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.5]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Jabberwocky}}
The jabberwock is a creature featured in ''Jabberwocky'', a famous nonsense poem by [[Wikipedia:Lewis Carroll|Lewis Carroll]], and its [[encyclopedia]] entry is an excerpt from the poem. ''Jabberwocky'' is first printed in Carroll's 1871 novel ''[[wikipedia:Through the Looking-Glass|Through the Looking-Glass]]'', the sequel to the 1865 ''[[wikipedia:Alice's Adventures in Wonderland|Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]''.

Alice finds herself in a looking-glass world and encounters the poem as part of a book written in a seemingly unintelligible language; she shortly discovers the text and the world at large is in fact inverted (or mirrored), and holds a mirror to the poem to read it, finding it as puzzling as the odd land she is now in. The poem is also the inspiration for the [[artifact weapon]] Vorpal Blade, based on the unnamed adventurer's weapon that is used to behead the jabberwock - this is also the basis for the jabberwock's weakness to Vorpal Blade.

The original illustrations by [[wikipedia:John Tenniel|John Tenniel]] accompanying the poem (and the rest of the two novels) depict the titular jabberwock as a bipedal creature that vaguely resembles a dragon: It has bat-like wings, a long serpentine neck, a long tail, a weird head with rabbit-like teeth, hands with three long spidery talons, and a waistcoat. Some of the jabberwock's more particular traits may reflect the contemporary Victorian obsession with natural history and the then-fast-evolving sciences of paleontology and geology.

==Messages==
{{message|The jabberwock burbles.|You [[chat]]ted to a jabberwock.}}

==Variants==
Many variants implement the vorpal jabberwock in some manner, while comparatively few make significant changes to the jabberwock itself.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], jabberwocks [[Hits creatures as +x weapon|hit as +1 weapons]].

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], weapons with the [[vorpal]] [[object property]] can also instantly behead jabberwocks.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], jabberwocks have an increased base level and damage dice that matches those of the vorpal jabberwock in vanilla ''NetHack''. A jabberwock can also follow you to other levels if it is adjacent, and will not generate in [[Gehennom]].

A jabberwock may be one of the monsters generated within a [[Special room (dNetHack)#Magic item vault|magic item vault]].

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
"Beware the Jabberwock, my son!
  The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun
  The frumious Bandersnatch!"

He took his vorpal sword in hand;
  Long time the manxome foe he sought --
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
  And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
  The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
  And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
  The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
  He went galumphing back.
|[ Jabberwocky, by Lewis Carroll ]
}}
